#Text=Stingray kills head diver of Underwater World Singapore
#Text=Friday , October 7 , 2016
#Text=Following an accidental death at the closed Underwater World Singapore ( UWS ) aquarium in Sentosa on Tuesday , operations to relocate the facility 's animals have been suspended .
#Text=File photo of a common stingray .
#Text=Image : Liné1 .
#Text=Phillip Chan , 62 , the head diver of the defunct facility , was moving stingrays in preparation for transfer to another aquarium when one of them stung him in the chest .
#Text=Singapore newspaper
#Text=The New Paper reported no prior such stingray incident was known to have occurred in Singapore .
#Text=Australian conservationist Steve Irwin died in a similar manner in 2006 .
#Text=Following a call to the Singapore Civil Defense Force at 2:20 pm , Chan was found near the entrance of UWS , where attempts were made to resuscitate him via CPR .
#Text=He was taken to Singapore General Hospital , where he died from his injuries .

#Text=While Chan 's colleagues declined to comment to The New Paper , a staff member at Shangri-La 's Rasa Sentosa Resort & Spa , who witnessed Chan being taken away by ambulance , stated , " It all happened very quickly .

column3:
_	_	_	_

#Text=UWS operator

#Text=Haw Par Corporation described Chan as a  veteran diver , aquarist and animal caregiver who had been caring for the aquatic animals at UWS since its opening in 1991 " .

column1: #Text=Ten staff , including Chan , remained at UWS after its closure on June 27 to facilitate care for its animals until they could be suitably relocated .

#Text=In addition to assisting the Ministry of Manpower 's ( MOM ) Occupational Safety and Health Inspectorate with their investigations , Haw Par has pledged Chan 's family " all possible support and assistance " .
#Text=Due to Chan 's death , MOM has ordered the cessation of animal transfers from UWS while investigations are pending .

#Text=In an interview with The New Paper , Dr. Tan Heok Hui , an ichthyologist and Lee Kong Chian Natural History Museum operations officer , stated , " Stingrays attack when they feel threatened , cornered or alarmed .

column3:
_	_	_	_

#Text=Stingray venom contains serotonin , a neurotransmitter that can induce severe muscle contractions .

#Text=According to Dr Tan ,  If a victim is hit in vital organs like the chest area , it may trigger a cardiac arrest , which could subsequently be fatal " .

column1: #Text=" Stingrays are not usually aggressive , and choose defensive methods to protect themselves .

column3:
_	_	_	_

#Text=In an interview with The New Paper at the time of UWS ' closure in June , Chan said of the animals he worked with , whom he described as his  band of friends " , " They are so quietly tame . [ ... ]

_	_	_	_

#Text=Chan 's work at UWS entailed diving into the tanks and feeding the animals whilst visitors took photos .
